title: NBA On Sling TV: How to Watch the Lakers vs. Cavaliers GameยOnline
summary: The NBA game tips off on Jan. 28 at 7 p.m. ET.
body: All products and services featured are independently chosen by editors. However, Billboard may receive a commission on orders placed through its retail links, and the retailer may receive certain auditable data for accounting purposes. LeBron James and the Los Angeles Lakers are set to take on the Cleveland Cavaliers today (Jan. 28) at Rocket Arena. Even though it’s been eight seasons since King James decided to leave his hometown team and join the purple and gold, NBA fans always get excited when the kid from Akron comes home. The Lakers and Cavs are having equally great seasons with both teams currently sitting at the 5th seed in their respective conferences with 28 wins so far. In the middle of his 23rd season, LeBron is averaging 22.4 points, 6.7 assists and 6 rebounds per game. With Luka Doncic putting up MVP numbers as well, the Cavs will need to step up their defense to stop the Lakers offensive fire power. When Does the Lakers vs. Cavs Game Start ? Lakers vs. Cavs game will start on Jan. 28 at 7 p.m. ET/4 p.m. PT at Rocket Arena in Cleveland. Where to Watch Lakers vs. Cavs Online The Lakers vs. Cavs game will broadcast live on ESPN but can be streamed through Sling Tโฆ

title: Networks Keeping NASAโs Artemis II Mission Connected
summary: NASAโs Artemis II mission will transport four astronauts around the Moon, bringing the agency one step closer to sending the first astronauts to Mars. Throughout Artemis II, astronaut voice, images, video, and vital mission data must traverse thousands of miles, carried on signals from NASAโs commuโฆ
body: 5 Min Read Networks Keeping NASAโs Artemis II Mission Connected An artist’s conceptual image of network antennas supporting the Orion spacecraft. Credits: NASA / Dave Ryan NASAโs Artemis II mission will transport four astronauts around the Moon, bringing the agency one step closer to sending the first astronauts to Mars. Throughout Artemis II, astronaut voice, images, video, and vital mission data must traverse thousands of miles, carried on signals from NASAโs communications systems. Through Artemis , NASA is establishing an enduring presence in space and exploring more of the Moon than ever before. To achieve this, Artemis missions rely on both the Near Space Network and the Deep Space Network. These networks, with oversight by NASAโs SCaN ( Space Communications and Navigation ) Program office, use global infrastructure and relay satellites to ensure seamless communications and tracking as Orion launches, orbits Earth, travels to the Moon, and returns home. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video NASAโs Artemis II mission will transport four astronauts around the Moon, bringing humanity closer to its joโฆ
